skill.name: startup-financial-modeling
skill.description: Build comprehensive 3-5 year financial models with revenue projections, cost structures, cash flow analysis, and scenario planning for early-stage startups.
skill.summary: Create realistic financial projections for startups including revenue forecasts, burn rate analysis, runway calculations, and scenario planning
skill.author: wshobson

security_audit.summary: This skill is safe to publish. It contains only markdown documentation about financial modeling for startups. The static scanner detected false positives - patterns like backticks and section headers were misinterpreted as code execution, and text containing words like 'cryptographic' or 'high' was flagged as weak crypto (both incorrect). This is pure educational content with no executable code.

content.value_statement: Build realistic 3-5 year financial models for your startup with revenue projections, burn rate analysis, and scenario planning. Calculate runway, estimate cash needs, and prepare for fundraising.
actual_capabilities: Build cohort-based revenue projections with retention modeling
Create detailed cost structures by category (COGS, S&M, R&D, G&A)
Calculate monthly cash flow and runway (months of cash remaining)
Model hiring plans with fully-loaded compensation estimates
Benchmark against industry ratios for early-stage startups
limitations: Cannot access real financial data or databases
Cannot execute code or generate actual spreadsheets
Models are estimates based on provided assumptions
Cannot predict future market conditions or customer behavior
No integration with accounting software or financial APIs

use_cases.title: Early-stage founders preparing for fundraising
use_cases.description: Generate financial projections to include in investor decks and pitch decks
use_cases.target_user: Startup founders and founders preparing for Series A/B fundraising rounds

use_cases.title: Startup teams planning hiring and growth
use_cases.description: Create headcount plans that align with revenue targets and burn rate
use_cases.target_user: Startup CEOs and founders planning team growth

use_cases.title: Business planning for new startups
use_cases.description: Build comprehensive business plans with financial scenarios and milestones

prompt_templates.title: Beginner: Build basic revenue projections
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a simple 3-year revenue projection for my startup. I have 100 initial customers paying $100/month. Our target retention rate is 80% each month. Show the monthly MRR for Year 1, and annual revenue for Years 2 and 3.

prompt_templates.title: Intermediate: Add costs and calculate runway
prompt_templates.prompt: Take the revenue projections from before and add a cost structure. Our monthly costs are: COGS 20% of revenue, S&M 40% of revenue, R&D 30% of revenue, G&A 10% of total expenses. We have $500,000 in current cash. Calculate monthly burn rate and runway (months of cash remaining) for each year.

prompt_templates.title: Advanced: Three-scenario analysis with fundraising
prompt_templates.prompt: Build a comprehensive 3-year financial model with three scenarios (conservative, base, optimistic). Include revenue projections, cost structure, hiring plan, and cash flow analysis. Assume we're raising $2M at $10M pre-money valuation. Show the runway with and without funding for each scenario. Include unit economics (CAC, LTV, payback period).

prompt_templates.title: Expert: Deep dive with cohort analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a detailed cohort-based revenue model for a B2B SaaS startup. Define the following: monthly new customer acquisitions, customer retention by month, ARPU growth over time, expansion revenue rates, and churn. Show the MRR trajectory for 36 months with monthly detail for Year 1, monthly detail for Year 2, and quarterly detail for Year 3. Calculate key metrics like LTV, CAC, payback period, and burn multiple for each year.

output_examples.input: Create a 3-year revenue projection for my SaaS startup. I have 50 customers paying $50/month, aiming for 20% monthly growth. My retention rate is 85% each month.
output_examples.output:
Here's your 3-year revenue projection:

**Year 1 - Monthly Breakdown:**
Month 1: $2,500 MRR (50 customers Ã— $50)
Month 2: $3,000 MRR (20% growth)
Month 3: $3,600 MRR
...
Month 12: $16,800 MRR

**Year 2 - Annual Projection:**
Revenue: $237,600
Average MRR: $19,800

**Year 3 - Annual Projection:**
Revenue: $422,400
Average MRR: $35,200

**Key Metrics:**
- Average retention: 85%
- Monthly growth: 20%
- Total 3-year revenue: $859,536

output_examples.input: Add costs to the revenue projection and calculate runway. We have $200,000 in cash. Monthly costs are 50% of revenue.
output_examples.output:
**Financial Model with Costs and Runway:**

**Year 1 Cash Flow:**
- Revenue: $85,560
- Expenses: $42,780 (50% of revenue)
- Net Burn: $42,780/month

**Year 2 Cash Flow:**
- Revenue: $237,600
- Expenses: $118,800
- Net Burn: $31,600/month

**Year 3 Cash Flow:**
- Revenue: $422,400
- Expenses: $211,200
- Net Burn: $21,600/month

**Runway Analysis (Starting with $200,000):**
- End of Year 1: -$260,640 (requires funding)
- Year 2 runway without funding: ~6 months
- Year 3 runway without funding: ~8 months

**Recommendation:** Raise $500K-750K to extend runway through Year 3 with buffer.

best_practices: Use conservative assumptions - startups rarely hit aggressive projections on day one
Include 20% buffer to expense estimates for unexpected costs
Model cash flow separately from revenue (payment terms affect runway)
Always include three scenarios - conservative, base, and optimistic
Validate your model against industry benchmarks and comparable companies
anti_patterns: Don't assume flat growth rates - customer acquisition typically follows S-curve patterns
Don't ignore churn - even good startups lose customers over time
Don't calculate runway based on revenue instead of cash received (payment terms matter)
Don't model headcount growth without accounting for hiring time and ramp-up periods
Don't present only optimistic projections to investors - show realistic scenarios

faq.question: What's the difference between burn rate and runway?
faq.answer: Burn rate is your monthly net cash loss (revenue minus expenses). Runway is how many months of cash you have remaining before running out of money, calculated as current cash balance divided by monthly burn rate.

faq.question: How do I calculate customer retention rate?
faq.answer: Retention rate is the percentage of customers who continue paying each month. For example, if you start with 100 customers and end the month with 95, your retention rate is 95%. Track retention by cohort to see how retention improves or degrades over time.

faq.question: What's a good LTV/CAC ratio for startups?
faq.answer: A healthy LTV/CAC ratio is typically 3:1 or higher. This means a customer is worth three times what you spent to acquire them. Below 3:1, your customer acquisition is too expensive and your business model may not be sustainable.

faq.question: How long should my financial model cover?
faq.answer: Build detailed monthly projections for the first 2 years, and quarterly for year 3. Use annual projections for years 4-5. This gives enough detail for planning while remaining realistic about uncertainty.

faq.question: What's the Rule of 40 for startups?
faq.answer: The Rule of 40 states that a software startup's growth rate plus profit margin should equal or exceed 40%. For example, a 30% growth rate with 10% margins (or 20% growth with 20% margins) is meeting the rule. It's a simple benchmark for growth-stage startups.

faq.question: How much should I raise in my funding round?
faq.answer: Raise enough to extend your runway 18-24 months plus achieve your next major milestone. Many founders raise 6-9 months of runway. Ensure you have enough to execute your plan without constant fundraising distractions.
